wonders.name: Great Wall of China
interesting_facts: The Great Wall is over 2,300 years old.
It stretches approximately 13,171 miles (21,196 km) in length.
Contrary to popular belief, it cannot be seen from space with the naked eye.
unique_facts: The wall was built by multiple dynasties, primarily to protect against invasions.
It is not a single continuous wall but a series of walls and fortifications.

wonders.name: Petra
interesting_facts: Petra is also known as the 'Rose City' due to the color of the stone.
It was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom in the 4th century BC.
The city was lost to the Western world for over 500 years.
unique_facts: Petra's most famous structure, Al-Khazneh (The Treasury), was carved directly into a sandstone cliff.
The city has a sophisticated water conduit system.

wonders.name: Christ the Redeemer
interesting_facts: The statue stands 98 feet (30 meters) tall, with arms stretching 92 feet (28 meters) wide.
It is made of reinforced concrete and soapstone.
It is one of the most iconic symbols of Christianity.
unique_facts: The statue was struck by lightning in 2014, damaging its fingers.
It was constructed in pieces and transported to the summit of Corcovado Mountain.

wonders.name: Machu Picchu
interesting_facts: Machu Picchu was built without the use of mortar, wheels, or iron tools.
It was rediscovered in 1911 by American historian Hiram Bingham.
The site is located 7,970 feet (2,430 meters) above sea level.
unique_facts: It is believed to have been a royal estate or sacred religious site for Inca rulers.
The stones are so precisely cut that not even a knife blade can fit between them.

wonders.name: Chichen Itza
interesting_facts: Chichen Itza was one of the largest Maya cities.
The pyramid El Castillo has 365 steps, representing the days of the year.
During the spring and autumn equinoxes, shadows create the illusion of a serpent descending the pyramid.
unique_facts: The site was a major center of political and economic power in the Maya civilization.
It features a large ball court where ritual games were played.

wonders.name: Roman Colosseum
interesting_facts: The Colosseum could hold between 50,000 and 80,000 spectators.
It was used for gladiatorial contests, animal hunts, and public spectacles.
The structure was damaged by earthquakes and stone robbers over the centuries.
unique_facts: It had a retractable awning called the velarium to shield spectators from the sun.
The Colosseum was built using concrete and sand, a revolutionary construction technique at the time.

wonders.name: Taj Mahal
interesting_facts: The Taj Mahal was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
It took approximately 22 years and 20,000 workers to complete.
The white marble changes color depending on the time of day.
unique_facts: The Taj Mahal is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered a symbol of eternal love.
The construction materials were brought from all over Asia, including jade, crystal, and turquoise.
